comments.commentBody: I once had a room like that - in my then home in Oakland CA and it was the perfect sleeping bubble.
" vaporous streaker"....That is beautiful writing. Thank you!

I sleep in a room surrounded by windows. Outside is a hill covered with trees, and a stream flows below. At night the moon awakens me so that I can view her beauty and that of her handmaids, the stars, and those naughty clouds who try to spoil the scene like some vaporous streaker. If I were an architect I would design houses with "sleeping bubbles"....rooms just a little larger than the bed, surrounded by windows like a green house.

This article of looking out windows reminded me of when I was looking out the window of an eight person cottage for people with intellectual/developmental disabilities on the grounds of Mansfield State Training School in Connecticut.  The year was 1984, my twenty-something enthusiasm envisioned the day that people would live in homes in the community, receive quality health care and be given the opportunity to be a friend and have friends too. That year my boss wrote in the annual performance evaluation as an area to work on "get your head out of the clouds and more down to earth with your thinking."  Sometimes are assumptions are for better futures. Over three decades later, my work allows me to visit, talk with and assess the quality of services these individuals enjoy for the most part.  "We all need to be more like that man."

The assertion that, by definition, rich people do not care about those poorer than they and do not endeavor to make things better for all Americans , or that they are so beholden to money that they would actually be bought by those who have it ("taking the Devil's money" as some campaign hatchet man recently proclaimed) is, on its face, simply silly .

Perhaps ed g is too young or too ill informed to remember the likes of Franklin Delano Roosevelt or John F. Kennedy, or Robert F. Kennedy . They, in constant Dollars, were infinitely wealthier than President and Secretary Clinton and yet they advocated, and in the case of the two Presidents, actually delivered, some of the most progressive legislation in the last 100 years . Lyndon Johnson, so reviled because of the Vietnam war, was also the force behind the Great Society which was able to raise millions of people out of abject poverty . He was also a very wealthy man .

Being wealthy is no sin . Not being rich is not necessarily indicative of virtue .

The idea that Americans acquire wisdom with age is laughable on its face.

I agree with MH. I think that the people who are often the most capable at the prime of their cognitive lives are woefully underrepresented. I think we need to insist that people aged 28 to 39 have a much greater voice in both political parties. I think it also grossly distorting that we have a system where you 'graduate' from elected position to position and thus almost all US senators are aged over 50. Perhaps one senator from each state needs to be a 'young' senator meaning that when elected they are not aged over 40. The other one can be over any age and we need to change the constitution to allow anyone to be a US Senator above she 18.

The whole issue of superdelegates begs a much larger question. Why should there be a system that so distorts the will of the people by having superdelegates, caucases that make participation very hard for most, and a system where we elect 'delegates'. It's time to modernize an eighteenth century model and have primaries that are directly proportionate to the number of votes cast, albeit at staggered intervals as is currently done. If one person achieves over 50% of the total votes vast they become the nominee. Otherwise we should have a national runoff primary election between all candidates who have obtained above 25% of the vote where the winner subsequently becomes the nominee. All votes should be weighed equally. Anything less is undemocratic.

The United States is not a direct democracy, but more of a Republic. This is becoming evident in this party election process as well, where these super delegates are the chosen representatives of the people in partial. I wish more context was given about their creation, in 1980, instead of just a 1 line reference.

The point this article doesn't mention is that the superdelegates aren't just preventing an activist candidate on the Democrat side, they are almost all the demographic that would already vote for Clinton. Most specifically I'd guess they are all over 37. There is a harsh dividing line between Sanders and Clinton based on age, and what the candidates provide. And by simple stature or lifetime wisdom inherent in these supposed superdelegates, they fall to the older side, and thus much more likely to side with Clinton. If superdelegates were spread across the age demographic, 18-65, I think we'd see a broader split.
